assumption: End-to-end training produces interpretable medical AI systems
hypothesis: Explicit region grounding significantly improves clinical interpretability without sacrificing performance
rationale: Clinicians require traceable reasoning paths from visual features to diagnostic conclusions for trust
testable_prediction: Region-aware models receive >30% higher interpretability scores from clinicians while maintaining accuracy
validation_method: Clinical evaluation study with radiologists rating model explanations

assumption: Fine-tuning general vision-language models suffices for medical domain adaptation
hypothesis: Domain-specific architectural changes are necessary for robust medical MLLM performance
rationale: Medical imaging has unique characteristics (anatomy, pathology patterns) not captured by natural image pretraining
testable_prediction: Domain-specific architectures outperform fine-tuned general models by >20% on cross-institution datasets
validation_method: Multi-center evaluation across different hospitals, patient populations, and imaging protocols

assumption: Concatenative multimodal fusion is optimal for medical vision-language tasks
hypothesis: Attention-based fusion with clinical knowledge integration outperforms standard concatenative approaches
rationale: Medical diagnosis requires integrating visual patterns with clinical context in non-linear ways
testable_prediction: Knowledge-integrated attention fusion improves diagnostic accuracy by >10% over concatenative baselines
validation_method: Ablation studies on multimodal fusion strategies using clinical datasets

assumption: AI performance metrics correlate with clinical utility
hypothesis: Clinical deployment success requires evaluation beyond traditional ML metrics
rationale: Real clinical value depends on workflow integration, trust, and decision support quality
testable_prediction: Models optimized for clinical metrics show >25% better adoption rates than accuracy-optimized models
validation_method: Prospective clinical trial measuring adoption rates, diagnostic confidence, and patient outcomes
